titleStmt.title: M109 [The Reader]. Typescript, fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 9p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: Numbered 26-27, 31, 34-35. Page 30 filed as p. 178 verso in her Between the Acts, later typescript with ms. fragment.
On verso of ms. page: [The moment and other essays. Mrs Thrale] typescript
On verso of p. 26-27: [Between the Acts] manuscript fragment

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: But under the celing ceiling , on the seats, there were gentlemen,
and noblemen, men versed in Latin and Greek; scholars,
courtiers, statesmen. Their silence was equally profound.
But their influence was also effective. ThxmxBaconsxxmxmx
Elizabeth and Essex and Bacon found what suited them too

in the
plyhouse playhouse

for ever weaving nets and threading mazes
mist must relax them
slves selves . The Queen must have players to divert her.

With all his craft and caution he himself
emdoies embodies
substantias substantiates
his meditations, gives them a body, a name a shape.

quote.l:
"Nay, retire men cannot, when they would:
neihter neither will they
when it were Reason: But are impatient of privateness

even in Age and Sicknesse, which require the
Sa dow [Shadow?] :

Like old
Townemen Townsmen that will still be sitting at their strete

d or door, those who thereby they offer
Agge Age to Scorn."

p.l:
Even the [crowd?] pressure of great
tho ts thoughts issue in a concrete shape.

These short meditations were
themslves themselves making it possible
for the dramatist to impart them where they seemed

i appropitae inappropriate . For Everything when times are
abobrent absorbent yields

some savour to the stew. The
i responsible irresponsible
mountbanks mountebanks ,

clothed in their
invisble invisible garment of anonymity were
Gos spies, in the streets, also at Court.

If at Grenwich or at
Whotehall Whitehall , one of them caught sight

of that grave
inscrutbale inscrutable figure, he could
uickly quickly add

him to
t the list of characters. And hyperbole, though the

gr ndl gs groundlings lusted
fot for it, required correction. Bacon

despsing despising
th the
thetre theatre for its hyperbole was
hel held contempt for the stage
w was medicinal. He was teaching them
to speak slowly, closely, subtly: to stiffen their

poetry with prose: A great age is like youth in
th the

individual. Any hint is heard. Any voice takes
effcet effect .

Criticism, a grave
an man
frwoning frowning in his corner of the royal

box is drawn into affecting the current. And so, as
th the seasons pass,

the aristocratic contempt
sevres severs to restrain; The
cabbbed crabbed

prose of Bacon is seized and
transfomred transformed . The plays are
